issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense
Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
I also observed this issue. Our perception system complains about timestamps not being properly ordered (e.g. having total ordering) every once in a while. This doesn't only happen on cloud machines, but any machine running a recent versions of gazebo from my observations.

Some WARN output from it fresh off a terminal:



```
#!

[ WARN] [1370294002.854665506, 29.741000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.016000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370294075.900793966, 89.320000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.029000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370294570.204259241, 488.230000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.015000 seconds

[ WARN] [1370294812.281200317, 683.600000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.015000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370294815.750032805, 686.362000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.014000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370294978.812621775, 817.250000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.014000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370295226.719163963, 1017.430000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.028000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370295270.934616938, 1052.730000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.015000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370295349.184839222, 1114.240000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.029000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370295408.998626802, 1162.721000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.014000 seconds
[ WARN] [1370295489.517599602, 1228.040000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.015000 seconds
```

content.html:
I also observed this issue. Our perception system complains about timestamps not being properly ordered (e.g. having total ordering) every once in a while. This doesn't only happen on cloud machines, but any machine running a recent versions of gazebo from my observations.

Some WARN output from it fresh off a terminal:

[ WARN] [1370294002.854665506, 29.741000000]: Stamp of point cloud to be inserted older or same as previous one, not inserting. Difference: -0.016000 seconds

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw: Just tested on the cloud and it looks like the amount of wrong timestamps goes up significantly as soon as both stereo images are subscribed. In that case, a lot of scans with duplicate timestamps seem to come in.
content.html: Just tested on the cloud and it looks like the amount of wrong timestamps goes up significantly as soon as both stereo images are subscribed. In that case, a lot of scans with duplicate timestamps seem to come in.

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense
Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
Rendering sensors, such as gpu laser and cameras, can have variable delays as opposed to a fixed 25 ms scan time. This was mainly implemented in order for multiple rendering based sensors to hit their target framerate. Multisense camera rendering updates are expensive so we allow other rendering sensors to "catch up" on their update if they got delayed. 

The duplicate timestamp is a bug.
content.html:
Rendering sensors, such as gpu laser and cameras, can have variable delays as opposed to a fixed 25 ms scan time. This was mainly implemented in order for multiple rendering based sensors to hit their target framerate. Multisense camera rendering updates are expensive so we allow other rendering sensors to "catch up" on their update if they got delayed.

The duplicate timestamp is a bug.

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
Okay, I want to make sure I understand.

The message header time (debugged) will tell us the start of a 25ms sweep,
but there will be time jitter between sweeps due to GPU availability. The sweep itself will have no internal timing jitter.

An alternative interpretation is that an entire sweep happens at the same time, given by the message header, rather than taking 25 msec to sample along the sweep path.

Another interpretation is that the sweep takes some other amount of time (say 12.5msec, or some time determined by the GPU).

If you can clarify the timing of each sample point relative to the message header time, that would be very helpful.
content.html:
Okay, I want to make sure I understand.

The message header time (debugged) will tell us the start of a 25ms sweep, but there will be time jitter between sweeps due to GPU availability. The sweep itself will have no internal timing jitter.

An alternative interpretation is that an entire sweep happens at the same time, given by the message header, rather than taking 25 msec to sample along the sweep path.

Another interpretation is that the sweep takes some other amount of time (say 12.5msec, or some time determined by the GPU).

If you can clarify the timing of each sample point relative to the message header time, that would be very helpful.

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
As long as we are clarifying how laser scanners work,
Is there an offset from the spinning axis to the actual laser.
If there is, is this information captured by the tf messages?
content.html: As long as we are clarifying how laser scanners work, Is there an offset from the spinning axis to the actual laser. If there is, is this information captured by the tf messages?

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
It's a combination of  your first and second interpretation.

The entire sweep happens at the same time, and there will be time jitter between sweeps due to GPU availability. 

Hope that helps.
content.html:
It's a combination of your first and second interpretation.

The entire sweep happens at the same time, and there will be time jitter between sweeps due to GPU availability.

Hope that helps.

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw:
Yes there is an offset. The laser scan messages have `frame_id = head_hokuyo_frame`,
and you can retrieve the offset by running:

`rosrun tf tf_echo hokuyo_link head_hokuyo_frame`. 

Thanks to @hsu  for the tip.
content.html:
Yes there is an offset. The laser scan messages have frame_id = head_hokuyo_frame, and you can retrieve the offset by running:

rosrun tf tf_echo hokuyo_link head_hokuyo_frame.

Thanks to @hsu for the tip.

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw: With current setup from .debs (normal, not nightly) I'm getting duplicate LIDAR stamps about every 2 seconds on average. This is on a Core i7 machine with Task 3 running at 0.41 RTF.
content.html: With current setup from .debs (normal, not nightly) I'm getting duplicate LIDAR stamps about every 2 seconds on average. This is on a Core i7 machine with Task 3 running at 0.41 RTF.

content.raw: Can a check on LIDAR timestamps to filter out duplicates in your subscribers work for now?
content.html: Can a check on LIDAR timestamps to filter out duplicates in your subscribers work for now?

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw: Yes, that's what we' re doing. But we're missing out on some of the data of course :)
content.html: Yes, that's what we' re doing. But we're missing out on some of the data of course :)

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw: Okay, but the scan at the same time has different data. Which one is the correct one?
content.html: Okay, but the scan at the same time has different data. Which one is the correct one?

issue.title: Laser scan timestamp does not make sense

content.raw: To clarify the problem: sensor updates are happening in the same physics timestep on the same scene so the base laser readings should be the same; the variations between duplicate timestamped laser data come from the random gaussian noise added to it. So I would say any one of the duplicate data should be fine.
content.html: To clarify the problem: sensor updates are happening in the same physics timestep on the same scene so the base laser readings should be the same; the variations between duplicate timestamped laser data come from the random gaussian noise added to it. So I would say any one of the duplicate data should be fine.
